Definition: Closed container of laboratory-grade water (or a matched blank matrix) that travels to the field location(s), remaining closed, that undergoes extraction & preparation alongside samples
Purpose: Identifies contaminants introduced from sampling containers
Minimum Guidance: Prepare a trip blank for each sample collection trip
Best Guidance: Prepare a trip blank for every n samples or sites*

Definition: Container of laboratory-grade water (or a matched blank matrix) that travels to the field location(s), is opened during sampling, that undergoes extraction & preparation alongside samples
Purpose: Identifies contaminants introduced during the act of sampling
Minimum Guidance: Prepare a field blank for each day of sample collection
Best Guidance: Prepare a field blank for every n samples or sites*

Definition: Container of laboratory-grade water (or a matched blank matrix) that is processed through the same equipment used during sampling, that undergoes extraction & preparation alongside samples
Purpose: Identifies contaminants introduced by specific tools or steps in sampling (e.g., pumps)
Minimum Guidance: Prepare an equipment blank for each sampling process involving tools that may affect sample collection
Best Guidance: Prepare an equipment blank for every n samples*

Definition: Laboratory-grade water (or a matched blank matrix) that undergoes extraction & preparation alongside samples, spiked with internal standards used in the study
Purpose: Identifies compounds introduced during sample preparation and measures the extraction efficiency of the sample preparation method without matrix
Minimum Guidance: Prepare a method blank for each set of prepared samples
Best Guidance: Prepare a method blank for every n samples^

Definition: Laboratory-grade water (or a matched blank matrix) that undergoes extraction & preparation alongside samples, spiked with internal standards and native compounds in the study
Purpose: Identifies the extraction efficiency of the sample preparation method without matrix to ensure accurate qualitative and quantitative data
Minimum Guidance: Prepare a method spike for each set of prepared samples or each matched matrix
Best Guidance: Prepare a method spike for every n samples^

Definition: A study sample duplicate or pooled sample that undergoes extraction & preparation alongside samples, spiked with internal standards and native compounds used in the study
Purpose: Identifies the extraction efficiency of the sample preparation method with matrix to ensure accurate qualitative and quantitative data
Minimum Guidance: Prepare a matrix spike for each matrix type in a set of prepared samples
Best Guidance: Prepare a matrix spike for every n samples^

Definition: A study sample collected and/or prepared in replicate that undergoes extraction & preparation alongside samples, spiked with internal standards used in the study
Purpose: Measures the reproducibility of the sample preparation method within a single sample matrix
Minimum Guidance: Prepare one duplicate sample for each set of prepared samples
Best Guidance: Prepare a duplicate sample for every n samples^

Definition: Diluent used to prepare final sample extracts, not spiked with any native or internal standards used in the study
Purpose: Identifies any presence of native or isotopically-labeled compounds present in the diluent or the instrument, due to carryover or contamination of mobile phases
Minimum Guidance: Inject a solvent blank at the start and end of each analytical batch
Best Guidance: Inject a solvent blank every n injections and before and after any samples containing spiked native compounds%

Definition: Diluent used to prepare final sample extracts, spiked with internal standards used in the study
Purpose: Measures the response of isotopically-labeled compounds in the same solvent composition as samples (excluding matrix). Can be used to ensure instrument performance is stable across injections/batches
Minimum Guidance: Prepare a laboratory blank for each set of samples and prepare a new laboratory blank if multiple diluents are used for a single batch of samples. Inject at the start of each analytical batch and at least two more times during the batch
Best Guidance: Inject a laboratory blank near the start of each analytical batch and every n injections within the batch%

Definition: Diluent used to prepare final sample extracts, spiked with native and internal standards used in the study
Purpose: Measures the response of both native and isotopically-labeled compounds in the same solvent composition as samples (excluding matrix). Can be used to ensure accurate quantification
Minimum Guidance: Prepare a control for each set of samples and prepare a new control if multiple diluents are used for a single batch of samples. Inject at the start of each analytical batch and at least two more times during the batch
Best Guidance: Inject a control near the start of each analytical batch and every n injections within the batch. If producing quantitative data using a calibration curve inject both a low concentration and mid-range concentration calibrant%

Definition: A set of study and QA/QC samples analyzed together on an instrument. Small studies may have few enough samples that all study and QA/QC samples can be analyzed within a single analytical batch. However, it is common for studies to require multiple analytical batches spread across days, months, and sometimes years for large studies
Purpose: The use of analytical batches ensures that instrument/signal drift is minimized and an instrument has sufficient “down time’ where calibration and routine maintenance can be performed
Minimum Guidance: Use QA/QC samples to track instrument and method performance over time and between batches
Best Guidance: Perform instrument calibration before and throughout each batch to ensure mass accuracy. Limit the number of runs per analytical batch to prevent drifting sensitivity due to poor chromatographic, ion source, or mass spectrometer performance. Spread replicate injections across analytical batches

Definition: Study and QA/QC samples injected in replicate to measure analytical variability
Purpose: These can be helpful in NTA studies to use for QA/QC filtering (described in Data Processing)
Minimum Guidance: Acquire a certain percentage or number of samples in duplicate or triplicate
Best Guidance: Acquire each study and QA/QC sample in triplicate

Definition: The order of study samples is randomized within and across analytical batches
Purpose: Instruments may have drifting sensitivity or performance across an analytical batch. Randomizing the order of which samples are injected can be helpful to minimize performance effects for entire groups of similar study or QA/QC samples
Minimum Guidance: Ensure instrument performance can be monitored using a combination of native and internal standards across study and QA/QC samples
Best Guidance: Randomize the order of all study and QA/QC samples within and across analytical batches

Definition: Instrument performance within and across analytical batches can be assessed using blanks (solvent, laboratory, or method blanks) and system suitability mixtures
Purpose: The performance of native and internal standards for the instrumental methods can be validated prior to a study and each analytical batch can be compared to original performance
Minimum Guidance: Inject a blank containing internal standards and system suitability mixture at least in triplicate for each analytical batch to track instrument and method performance
Best Guidance: Inject a blank containing internal standards and a system suitability mixture every n samples to track instrument and method performance. If quantitative data is generated with a calibration curve, consider running both a low-range (near the method reporting limit) and a mid-range concentration%
